problem: How much work is required to stop an electron moving at a speed of 1.40 × 10⁶ m/s? (Given: mass of electron m = 9.11 × 10⁻³¹ kg)

steps.explanation: We will use the work-energy theorem and kinetic energy formula
Define variables with values given in the problem
steps.notations: mₑ = 9.11 × 10⁻³¹ kg, vᵢ = 1.40 × 10⁶ m/s, v_f = 0 m/s (stopped)

steps.explanation: The work equals the change in kinetic energy from initial to final state
steps.notations: W = ΔKE = KE_f − KE_i = ½mₑv_f² − ½mₑvᵢ²

steps.explanation: Since the electron stops, the final velocity is zero
Substitute the numerical values into the formula
Calculate the square of the velocity
Complete the calculation to find the work
The negative sign indicates work is done on the electron to stop it; the magnitude is the work required

solution:
W = ΔKE = KE_f − KE_i
KE = ½mv²
W = ½mₑv_f² − ½mₑvᵢ²
Given: mₑ = 9.11 × 10⁻³¹ kg, vᵢ = 1.40 × 10⁶ m/s, v_f = 0 m/s
W = ½mₑ(0)² − ½mₑvᵢ² = −½mₑvᵢ²
W = −½(9.11 × 10⁻³¹ kg)(1.40 × 10⁶ m/s)²
W = −½(9.11 × 10⁻³¹)(1.96 × 10¹²) kg·m²/s²
W = −8.9 × 10⁻¹⁹ J
Work required = 8.9 × 10⁻¹⁹ J
